meanings.definition: To force into a narrow space
meanings.sent1: She was wedging the puzzle pieces together to make them fit.
meanings.sent2: The carpenter was wedging the door into its frame.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel was wedging the acorn into a tiny crack for safekeeping.
meanings.sent4: He felt like he was wedging himself into a corner with no way out.
meanings.sent5: The chef demonstrated wedging the knife between the garlic cloves to peel them easily.

meanings.definition: To insert or fix tightly into a space
meanings.sent1: He was wedging the key into the lock to open the door.
meanings.sent2: The mechanic was wedging the new tire onto the rim.
meanings.sent3: The kids were wedging their feet into shoes that were too small for them.
meanings.sent4: She felt like she was wedging her way into a conversation that didn't involve her.
meanings.sent5: The artist was wedging the brush into the paint to create bold strokes on the canvas.

meanings.definition: The act of forcing something into a narrow space
meanings.sent1: The wedging of the bookshelf into the corner was a tight squeeze.
meanings.sent2: The wedging of the last piece into the puzzle completed the picture.
meanings.sent3: The wedging of the oversized box into the small car trunk was a comical sight.
meanings.sent4: The wedging of the words into the speech made it difficult to understand.
meanings.sent5: The wedging of the final ingredient into the recipe brought the dish together perfectly.
